myxo: <entryFree id="n30321" type="greek" key="myxo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">myxo</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">myxon</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">mu/cwn</foreign>, <sense id="n30321.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fish, also called</hi> bacchus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 7, 25, § 77</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
myxos: <entryFree id="n30322" type="spur" key="myxos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">myxos</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">myxus</orth>, a false read. for myxa, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:41:2" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 41, 2</bibl>.</entryFree>
myxum: <entryFree id="n30323" type="main" key="myxum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">myxum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>myxa</etym>, <sense id="n30323.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the fruit of the</hi> myxa, <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 3, 25 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; Gargil. Mart. Medic. ex Rom. § 15. <cb n="N." /></sense></entryFree>
n: <entryFree id="n30324" type="main" key="N"><orth extent="full" lang="la">N</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">n</orth>, <itype>had its full</itype>, pure sound only when it began a syllable; in the middle or at the end of a word it was weakened. Hence the remark of Priscian (p. 556 P.): <sense id="n30324.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">n</hi> quoque plenior in primis sonat, et in ultimis partibus syllabarum, ut nomen, stamen; exilior in mediis, ut amnis, damnum, is not accurate, v. Corss. Ausspr. 1, p. 248 sq. Between two vowels, the single <hi rend="ital">n</hi> frequently takes the place, in MSS. and inscriptions, of double <hi rend="ital">n;</hi> thus: Pescenius, Porsena, conubium, conecto, conitor, coniveo. The <hi rend="ital">n</hi> of con- for com- often falls away before <hi rend="ital">h;</hi> as: cohaerere, coheres, cohibere, cohors; and before <hi rend="ital">j;</hi> as: coicere, cojux or cojunx, cosul, etc. In very late Latin, <hi rend="ital">n</hi> was frequently dropped before <hi rend="ital">s</hi> in the participial ending -ans, -ens, and before <hi rend="ital">st, scr</hi>, or simple <hi rend="ital">s</hi> in composition. In the earlier language<cb n="NACO" />  this occurs in the ending -iens; as: quoties, toties, vicies, for quotiens, etc.; and in a few other instances, as castresis for castrensis; formosus for the older form formonsus; and in inscriptions, meses for menses, tösor for tonsor, etc.; cf. also, quăsi for quansi (quam si). Before the guttural letters a medial <hi rend="ital">n</hi> receives the sound of Greek <foreign lang="greek">g</foreign> before gutturals, wherefore, in early times, viz., by Attius, we have also <hi rend="ital">g</hi> written for <hi rend="ital">n</hi>: Agchises, agceps, aggulus, aggens, agguilla, iggerunt, etc., Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 556</bibl> P. (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. p. 264" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. p. 264</bibl> Müll.); cf. Mar. Victor. p. 2462 and 2465 P.; hence called <hi rend="ital">n</hi> adulterinum by Nigid. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:14:7.Assimilation" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 14, 7.Assimilation</bibl> commonly takes place before <hi rend="ital">l, m</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">r</hi>: illabor, immitto, irrumpo (v. <hi rend="ital">in</hi>), yet is often neglected; before the labials, <hi rend="ital">n</hi> is commonly changed into <hi rend="ital">m</hi>: imberbis, imbutus; impar, impleo; and before initial <hi rend="ital">m</hi> the preposition <hi rend="ital">in</hi> is frequently written <hi rend="ital">im</hi>, v. Prol. <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> p. 433</bibl> Rib.The letter <hi rend="ital">n</hi> is frequently <hi rend="ital">inserted</hi>, particularly before <hi rend="ital">s</hi>: me<hi rend="ital">n</hi>sis, e<hi rend="ital">n</hi>sis, ansa; Megalesia and Megalensia, frons and frus. Less freq. before other consonants: tu<hi rend="ital">n</hi>do, ju<hi rend="ital">n</hi>go, mi<hi rend="ital">n</hi>go, pu<hi rend="ital">n</hi>go, etc.; cf. also: lanterna and laterna, ligula and lingula. Sometimes <hi rend="ital">n</hi> is inserted with a vowel: fru-niscor from fruor, and perh. fenestra from festra. The double forms, alioquin and alioqui, ceteroqui and ceteroquin, seem to rest on purely phonetic grounds, v. h. vv.As an abbreviation, N usually stands for natus, nefastus dies, nepos, nomine, novum, the praenomen Numerius, numero, numine.—N = natione, natus, nostri, nostro, etc., numerus, numero, etc. N. D. N. = numini domini nostri. N. L. = non liquet (v. liqueo). N. M. V. = nobilis memoriae vir. NN. BB. = nobilissimi. NP. = nefastus prior. NVM. = nummum. In poetry, <hi rend="ital">n</hi> alone sometimes stands for the enclitic <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>, even before a consonant: <cit><quote lang="la">nostin quae sit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:319" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 319</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 797 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
nabataea: <entryFree id="n30325" type="main" key="Na^ba^taea"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Năbătaea</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Năbăthaea</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nabataia</foreign>, <sense id="n30325.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a country in Arabia Petræa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 18, 72, § 120</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n30325.1" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Năbă-thaeus</orth> (scanned Năbătaeus, Năbāthaeus, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Carm. 5, 284</bibl>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nabaqai=os</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Nabathæa, Nabathœan</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">saltus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:11:126" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 11, 126</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Năbătaei</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Năbăthaei</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nabatai=oi</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">*nabaqai=oi</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the Nabathæans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 28, 32, § 144</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:98" default="NO" valid="yes">12, 20, 44, § 98</bibl>; Auct. B. Alex. 1, 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 57</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 8, 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30325.2" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, transf., for <hi rend="ital">Arabian, Eastern, Oriental</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Eurus ad Auroram Nabathaeaque regna recessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nabathaei flatus Euri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 4, 63</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30325.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Năbăthes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a Nabathæan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Oet. 160" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Oet. 160</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nabdalsa:
<entryFree id="n30326" type="main" key="Nabdalsa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nabdalsa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30326.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a distinguished Numidian, a general of Jugurtha</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 70:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 70, 2</bibl>.
†† </sense><sense id="n30326.1" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">nabis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">nabun</orth> <etym>Ethiopic</etym>, <hi rend="ital">a camelopard</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 18, 27, § 69</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nabis: <entryFree id="n30327" type="main" key="Nabis" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nabis</orth>, <itype>idis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*na/bis</foreign>, <sense id="n30327.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a king of Sparta, about</hi> 200 B. C., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:12:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 12, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:25:3" default="NO" valid="yes">31, 25, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:24:6" default="NO" valid="yes">34, 24, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nablia: <entryFree id="n30328" type="main" key="nablia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nablia</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, v. naulia.</entryFree>
nablio: <entryFree id="n30329" type="gloss" key="nabli^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nablĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30329.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who plays the</hi> nablium (naulium): nablio, <foreign lang="greek">ya/lths</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
nablium: <entryFree id="n30330" type="main" key="nabli^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nablĭum</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">nablum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n30330.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a musical instrument of ten or twelve strings, played with both hands; a kind of harp, of Phœnician origin</hi>, i. q. naulium.—Form nablium, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:327" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 327</bibl>.—Form nablum, <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> 1</bibl> Chron. 15, 16 sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,023:13:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1 Macc. 13, 51</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nablizo: <entryFree id="n30331" type="gloss" key="nablizo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nablizo</orth>, <itype>1</itype>, <sense id="n30331.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. a., to play the</hi> nablium (naulium): nablizo, <foreign lang="greek">ya/llw</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
nabun: <entryFree id="n30332" type="main" key="nabun"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nabun</orth>, v. 1. nabis.</entryFree>
nacca: <entryFree id="n30333" type="greek" key="nacca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nacca</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nacta</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">natta</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">na/kths</foreign> (pure Lat. fullo), <sense id="n30333.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fuller</hi>: naccae appellantur vulgo fullones, ut ait Curiatius, quod nauci non sint, i. e. nullius pretii. Idem sentit et Cincius. Quidam aiunt, quod omnia fere opera ex lanā nacae dicantur a Graecis, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=166" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 166</bibl> Müll.; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9, p. 227, 22</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naccinus: <entryFree id="n30334" type="main" key="nacci_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naccīnus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">nactīnus</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nacca</etym>, <sense id="n30334.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a fuller</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naccina truculentia, i. e. fullonis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9, p. 229, 36</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nacolea: <entryFree id="n30335" type="main" key="Naco^le_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nacŏlēa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Nacŏlīa</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Nacolĭa</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nako/leia, *nakolia</foreign>, <sense id="n30335.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Great Phrygia</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 26, 9, 7</bibl>. <cb n="NAM" /></sense></entryFree>
nacta: <entryFree id="n30336" type="main" key="nacta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nacta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, v. nacca.</entryFree>
nactus: <entryFree id="n30337" type="main" key="nactus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nactus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from nanciscor.</entryFree>
nae: <entryFree id="n30338" type="main" key="nae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nae</orth>, vulgar form for <orth extent="full" lang="la">nē</orth> (v. 3. ne), particle of assurance, <sense id="n30338.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">verily, truly</hi>.</sense></entryFree>
naenia: <entryFree id="n30339" type="main" key="naeni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naenĭa</orth>, v. nenia.</entryFree>
naevia: <entryFree id="n30340" type="main" key="Naevi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naevĭa porta</orth>, v. 2. Naevius, A.</entryFree>
naevianus: <entryFree id="n30341" type="main" key="Naevi^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naevĭānus</orth>, v. 2. Naevius, B.</entryFree>
naevius: <entryFree id="n30342" type="main" key="naevi^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naevĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>naevus</etym>, <sense id="n30342.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that has a mole</hi> on his body, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 3, 108</bibl> dub. (al. naevinos).</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30343" type="main" key="Naevi^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naevĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype> <etym>naevus; hence, prop., one born with a mole or birth-mark</etym>, <sense id="n30343.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens. The most celebrated member of it is Cn. Naevius, <hi rend="ital">a Roman epic and dramatic poet, born</hi> A. U. C. 480. <hi rend="ital">He made the first Punic war, in which he had served, the subject of a poem, in which he so boldly satirized the nobility, especially the Metelli, that he was forced into exile at Utica, where he died</hi>, A. U. C. 550, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:15:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 15, 60</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:1:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:24:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 24, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:21:45" default="NO">17, 21, 45</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n30343.1" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Naevĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a Nævius, Nœvian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">porta Naevia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 11</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=163" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 163</bibl> Müll.: Naevia silva dicta juxta Romam, quod Naevi cujusdam fuerit, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=168" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 168</bibl> ib.: <cit><quote lang="la">Naevia olea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:48" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 48</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30343.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Naevĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Nævian;</hi> i. e., </sense><sense id="n30343.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the poel Nævius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hector,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scripta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">modi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30343.4" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to</hi> (<hi rend="ital">another</hi>) <hi rend="ital">Nævius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pira,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:10:18" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 10, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:10:4" default="NO">12, 10, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 24</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naevulus: <entryFree id="n30344" type="main" key="naevu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naevŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>naevus</etym>, <sense id="n30344.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little mole</hi> on the body, <hi rend="ital">a wart</hi> (post-Aug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:1:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 1, 7</bibl>: minores aliae insulae, ut naevuli quidam, per apertas Ponti sunt sparsae regiones, App. de Mundo, p. 59, 27; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1248,001:Ep. 1:2" default="NO"><author>Fronto</author> Ep. 1, 2 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl> Mai.</sense></entryFree>
naevus: <entryFree id="n30345" type="main" key="naevus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naevus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>for gnaevus, root gna-, gen-, of genus, gnatus, a mark born with one; cf.: natus, natura, etc.</etym>, <sense id="n30345.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mole</hi> or <hi rend="ital">wart</hi> on the body. </sense><sense id="n30345.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">naevus in articulo pueri... est corporis macula naevus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:28:79" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 28, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">egregio inspersos reprehendas corpore naevos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 6, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullus in egregio corpore naevus erit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:13:14" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 13, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 25, 67, § 137</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:34" default="NO" valid="yes">28, 4, 6, § 34</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30345.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a spot, blemish, fault</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">naevi instar est, ut frater meus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:34" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> 3, 34</bibl></cit> dub.</sense></entryFree>
nahanarvali: <entryFree id="n30346" type="main" key="Nahanarva_li"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nahanarvāli</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30346.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Germanic people, belonging to the race of the Lygians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 43</bibl> (this the better read., v. Orell. ad h. l.; al. Naharvali).</sense></entryFree>
naharvali: <entryFree id="n30347" type="main" key="Naharvali"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naharvali</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, v. Nahanarvali.</entryFree>
naias: <entryFree id="n30348" type="main" key="Na_i^a^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nāĭăs</orth>, <itype>ădis</itype>, and more freq. <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nāĭs</orth>, <itype>ĭdis and ĭdos</itype> (<number>plur.</number> ĭdas), <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nai+a/s</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">*nai(s</foreign> (floating, swimming, that is in the water), <sense id="n30348.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a water-nymph, Naiad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illum fontana petebant Numina, Naïades,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:328" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 328</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aegle Naïadum pulcherrima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Naïs Amalthēa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:115" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 115</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> of mixing wine with water: <cit><quote lang="la">Naïda Bacchus amat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:6:57" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 3, 6, 57</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">puellae Naïdes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:10:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 10, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30348.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">a nymph</hi> (Hamadryad, Nereid): <cit><quote lang="la">Naïda vulneribus succidit in arbore factis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:231" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 231</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inter Hamadryadas celeberrima Naias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:691" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 1, 691</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Naïdes aequoreae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:14:557" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 557</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30348.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The surname probably of a freedwoman</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Servilia Naïs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:3" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 3</bibl></cit>.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nāĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of the Naids, proceeding from the Naids</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dona,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:32:40" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 32, 40</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30348.3" n="B" level="2"> As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nāĭcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a Roman surname</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 241</bibl>, col. 2.— In <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">‡ Nāĭcē</orth>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Fabr.</author> p. 650</bibl>, n. 433.</sense></entryFree>
nais: <entryFree id="n30349" type="main" key="Na_i^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nāĭs</orth>, <itype>idis and ĭdos</itype>, v. Naias.</entryFree>
nam: <entryFree id="n30350" type="main" key="nam"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nam</orth>, <sense id="n30350.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi> [<hi rend="ital">acc. sing. fem.</hi> of pronom. stem na-; cf.: <foreign lang="greek">e)gw/-nh, tu/-nh</foreign>; Lat. ne, nae; <hi rend="ital">masc.</hi> num; cf.: tum, tam; quom, quam]. </sense><sense id="n30350.1" n="I" level="1"> To introduce a confirmation or explanation, <hi rend="ital">for</hi> (always in prose beginning the sentence; cf.: enim, etenim, and <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr> C.). </sense><sense id="n30350.2" n="A" level="2"> Introducing an explanation or fuller statement of something already said. </sense><sense id="n30350.3" n="1" level="3"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">is pagus appellabatur Tigurinus. Nam omnis civitas Helvetia in quattuor pagos divisa est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:12:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 12, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus rebus auditis ... suas quoque copias in tres partes distribuerunt. Nam praesidio e regione castrorum relicto ... reliquas copias, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 61, 5</bibl></cit>: neque solum colent inter se ac diligent, sed etiam verebuntur. Nam maximum ornamentum amicitiae tollit, qui ex eā tollit verecundiam, Cic. <pb n="1185" /> <cb n="NAM" /> Lael. 22, 82; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Part. Or. 11, 38</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 43, 147</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">pandite atque aperite propere januam hanc Orci, opsecro. Nam equidem haut aliter esse duco,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 1, 2</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n30350.4" n="2" level="3"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n30350.5" n="(a)" level="5"> To introduce an explanatory parenthetical clause: <cit><quote lang="la">omni ratione colenda justitia est, tum ipsa per sese (nam aliter justitia non esset), tum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:12:42" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 12, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et in insulā quae est in Fibreno —nam hoc, opinor, illi alteri flumini nomen est—sermoni reliquo demus operam sedentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:1:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tamen is ad id locorum talis vir (nam postea ambitione praeceps datus est), consulatum adpetere non audebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 63:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 63, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 40:9" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 40, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30350.6" n="(b)" level="5"> To resume the course of thought after a parenthetical interruption: <cit><quote lang="la">hic vero simul ... atque me mare transisse cognovit (audi, audi, atque attende ...), nam simul ac me Dyrrachium attigisse audivit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:41:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 41, 98</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duplex inde Hannibali gaudium fuit (neque enim quidquam eorum, quae apud hostes agerentur, eum fallebat): nam et liberam Minucii temeritatem se suo modo capturum, et sollertiae Fabii dimidium virium decessisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:28:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 28, 1</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n30350.7" n="(g)" level="5"> To introduce an example, or several examples, illustrating a general statement, <hi rend="ital">for example, for instance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed vivo Catone minores natu multi uno tempore oratores floruerunt. Nam et A. Albinus ... et litteratus et disertus fuit. Nam Q. Metellus ... in primis est habitus eloquens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:21:81" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 21, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin etiam easdem causas ut quisque egerit utile erit scire. Nam de domo Ciceronis dixit Calidius, et pro Milone orationem Brutus exercitationis gratiā scripsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:23" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:38" default="NO">8, 6, 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3</bibl> (4), 1, 23.—</sense><sense id="n30350.8" n="B" level="2"> Introducing a ground or reason for a fact, command, or principle. </sense><sense id="n30350.9" n="1" level="3"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">quamobrem, Quirites, celebratote illos dies cum conjugibus ac liberis vestris: nam multi saepe honores dīs immortalibus justi habiti sunt, sed profecto justiores numquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:10:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 3, 10, 23</bibl></cit>: vires vitaque corpus meum nunc deserit omne: nam me visus homo pulcher, etc., Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:20:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 20, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui ... dilectum habere noluerit. Nam sociorum auxilia aut ita imbecilla sunt, ut non multum nos juvare possint, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 15, 1, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30350.10" n="2" level="3"> Esp., introducing the speaker's reason for a particular form of statement, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">Phoenices alias urbes in orā maritumā condidere ... nam de Carthagine silere melius puto quam parum dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 19:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 19, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Mercuri (nam te docilis magistro Movit Amphion lapides canendo), etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 11, 1</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so in a question: una domus erat, idem victus isque communis ... nam quid ego de studiis dicam cognoscendi semper aliquid, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:27:104" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 27, 104</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quid ego de cotidiano sermone querimoniāque populi Romani loquar?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:49:section=129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 49, § 129</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30350.11" n="3" level="3"> Loosely, introducing the speaker's reason for saying what precedes: nam ego ad Menaechmum nunc eo (<hi rend="ital">I have said this</hi>), <hi rend="ital">for</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 1, 1, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 1, 1, 3</bibl> Brix ad loc.—So esp. after a general remark, introducing its illustration in the case in hand, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:1:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 1, 1, 58</bibl> Spengel ad loc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 5, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 2, 1, 17</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30350.12" n="4" level="3"> In a still looser connection, introducing a particular fact or argument in support of what precedes, <hi rend="ital">but, now, certainly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">L. Sisennae omnis facultas ex historiā ipsius perspici potest, quae cum facile vincat superiores, tum indicat quantum absit a summo ... Nam Q. Hortensii admodum adulescentis ingenium simul aspectum et probatum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:64:228" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 64, 228</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">43, 161</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:31:66" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 31, 66</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 32, 68</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">at prooemium aliquando et narrationem dicit malus homo et argumenta sic, ut nihil sit in his requirendum. Nam et latro pugnabit acriter, virtus tamen erit fortitudo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:20:10" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 20, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30350.13" n="5" level="3"> Ellipt., in reply to a question or remark, where the answer is implied, and nam introduces the reason for it; <hi rend="ital">for assuredly, certainly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nos hunc Heracliensem, multis civitatibus expetitum ... de nostrā civitate eiciemus? Nam si quis minorem gloriae fructum putat ex Graecis versibus percipi quam ex Latinis, vehementer errat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:10:22 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 10, 22 sq.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquid ergo hic Lysimachus, felicitate quādam dentibus leonis elapsus, ob hoc cum ipse regnaret mitior fuit? Nam Telesphorum Rhodium amicum suum ... in caveā velut novum animal aliquod ... pavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:de Ira. 3:17:3" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> de Ira. 3, 17, 3</bibl></cit>; cf.: de eis rebus, <cb n="NAM" /> inquit Crassus, quibus sciam poteroque. Tum ille: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quod tu non poteris aut nescies, quis nostrum tam impudens est, qui se scire aut posse postulet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:22:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 22, 101</bibl></cit>.—So with particles of asseveration: mehercule, hercule, edepol, etc.: tamen tibi a me nulla orta est injuria. <hi rend="ital">Aes.</hi> Nam hercle etiam hoc restat, i. e. <hi rend="ital">not yet; for that is to come hereafter</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 2, 1, 36</bibl>: sume, posce, prome quidvis: te facio cellarium. <hi rend="ital">Er.</hi> Nam nisi hercle manticinatus probe ero, fusti pectito, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 115</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicunt ei fere nullam esse columnam, quae ad perpendiculum esse possit. Nam mehercule, inquit, sic agamus: columnae ad perpendiculum exigantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:51:section=133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 51, § 133</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30350.14" n="C" level="2"> The conjunction nam sometimes follows a word of the clause (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and perh. not ante-Aug.; v. Lachm. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:page=246" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> p. 246</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">prohibent nam cetera Parcae Scire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:379" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 379</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">solam nam perfidus ille Te colere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 421</bibl></cit>; 10, 585; <cit><quote lang="la">1, 444: olim nam quaerere amabam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego nam videor mihi sanus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 302</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">his nam plebecula plaudit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 186</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n30350.15" n="II" level="1"> In transitions. </sense><sense id="n30350.16" n="A" level="2"> Introducing a new subject as of secondary importance; <hi rend="ital">but now, on the other hand</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quod rumores distulerunt malivoli, Multas contamināsse Graecas, dum facit Paucas Latinas: factum hic esse id non negat, Neque se pigere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:prol. 19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. prol. 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quod purgas eos, quos ego mihi scripsi invidisse, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:15:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 3, 15, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quod negas te dubitare quin magnā in offensā sim apud Pompeium hoc tempore, non video causam cur ita sit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 2</bibl></cit>, a, 2; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:13:47" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 13, 47</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam auguralis libros ad commune utriusque nostrum otium serva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:11:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 11, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam Vestae nomen a Graecis est, i. e. though that of Janus, before named, is Latin,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:27:67" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 27, 67</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:31:66" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 31, 66</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 32, 68</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:11:7" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 11, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:9" default="NO">10, 1, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30350.17" n="B" level="2"> Esp., in referring to a consideration too obvious to require discussion, <hi rend="ital">for obviously, for it is certain</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">postremo hoc in pectus tuum demitte, numquam populum Romanum beneficiis victum esse: nam bello quid valeat, tute scis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 102:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 102, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:26:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 26, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:23:52" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 23, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 76</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n30350.18" n="III" level="1"> In interrogations, emphatically, expressing wonder or emotion in the questioner; cf. Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ga/r</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n30350.19" n="A" level="2"> With an interrogative. </sense><sense id="n30350.20" n="1" level="3"> Beginning a sentence (anteclass. and <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): perdidisti omnem operam? <hi rend="ital">Ep.</hi> Nam quī perdidi? <hi rend="ital">but how? but why?</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quem ego adspicio?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 5, 3, 3</bibl></cit>: quid ego ago? <hi rend="ital">Tr.</hi> Nam quid tu, malum, me rogitas quid agas? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:1:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 2, 1, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quae haec anus est exanimata a fratre quae egressa'st meo?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quid ita?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:2:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 2, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quem? alium habui neminem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 4, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quam ob rem? (= quamnam),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quā me causā extrusisti ex aedibus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:1:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 1, 1, 5</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quis te, juvenum confidentissime, nostras Jussit adire domos?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:445" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 445</bibl></cit> (but cf. Forbig. ad loc. and Kritz ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 19:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 19, 2</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">nam quae tam sera moratur Segnities?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:A. 2:373" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 373</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellua multorum es capitum. Nam quid sequar aut quem?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 76</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30350.21" n="2" level="3"> Joined as enclitic to an interrogative word: <cit><quote lang="la">quinam homo hic ante aedīs nostras conqueritur?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:4:9:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 4, 9, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quidnam id est?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:5:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 5, 2, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quisnam igitur tuebitur P. Scipionis memoriam mortui?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:36:section=80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 36, § 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">O di immortales, ubinam gentium sumus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 4, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:10:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 10, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed Allobroges diu in incerto habuere quidnam consilii caperent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 41:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 41, 1</bibl></cit>.—For quianam, v. quia <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n30350.22" n="3" level="3"> Separated from the interrogative word: <cit><quote lang="la">quid tibi ex filio nam, obsecro, aegre est?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis ea'st nam optuma?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 1, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 2, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid cerussa opus nam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 3, 101</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis est nam ludus in undis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:9:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 9, 39</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30350.23" n="4" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">num</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">num tibi nam, amabo, janua est mordax mea?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">num quid nam tibi molestum est, gnate mi, si, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 5, 1, 3</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">comicum est et Terentianum numquidnam, cum exemptis num et nam sufficere ad interrogationem potuisset quid,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Donat.</author> ad Ter. And. 1, 4, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">num nam haec audivit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">num quid nam de oratore ipso restat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:7:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Part. Or. 7, 26</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30350.24" n="B" level="2"> Without an interrogative word (very rare): <cb n="NANC" /> scis nam tibi quae praecepi? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:3:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 3, 1, 51</bibl>. (For fuller details, v. Hand, Turs. 4, pp. 1-22.)</sense></entryFree>
nama: <entryFree id="n30351" type="gloss" key="na_ma"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāma</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">na=ma</foreign>, <sense id="n30351.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fluid, liquid</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">DEDICAVIT NAMA CVNCTIS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1914</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">NAMA SEBESIO,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1915</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
namnetes: <entryFree id="n30352" type="main" key="Namne_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Namnētes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30352.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people in Celtic Gaul, near the site of Nantes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 9, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 18, 32, § 107</bibl>.—In <number>sing.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Namnis</orth>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 188</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30352.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the capital of the Namnetes, the modern Nantes</hi>, Ven. Ep. 3.</sense></entryFree>
namque: <entryFree id="n30353" type="main" key="namque"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nam-que</orth> (also written <orth extent="full" lang="la">nanque</orth>), <sense id="n30353.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">cong.</hi>, an emphatic confirmative particle, a strengthened nam, closely resembling that particle in its uses, but introducing the reason or explanation with more assurance; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">kai ga/r</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">for indeed, for truly, for</hi> (class. and freq., only before a vowel, and in Cicero and Cæsar always, like nam, beginning the proposition; <cit><quote lang="la">rarely before a consonant, and not in Cæs.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:30:62" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 30, 62</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 2, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:20:65" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 3, 20, 65</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ages. 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 41:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 41, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:85:35" default="NO" valid="yes">85, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0530,001:B. G. 8:28:4" default="NO"><author>Hirt.</author> B. G. 8, 28, 4</bibl>; Ant. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:20:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 13, 20, 45</bibl>; Balb. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 13</bibl>, A. 2; and freq. in Liv.; v. Krebs, Antibarb. p. 732 sq.): pol mihi fortuna magis nunc defit quam genus: namque regnum suppetebat mi, etc., Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:19:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 19, 44</bibl> (Trag. v. 395 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">namque ita me di ament,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 1, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in quo vix dicere audeo, quam multa saecula hominum teneantur. Namque ut olim deficere sol hominibus exstinguique visus est, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:22:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 22, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">namque illud quare, Scaevola, negāsti? etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:16:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 16, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">namque hoc praestat amicitia propinquitati, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:5:19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 5, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">namque tum Thraces eas regiones tenebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 1, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Them. 6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,007:1:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Alc. 1, 2 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">namque umeris suspenderat arcum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:318" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 318</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">390</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">namque etsi, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 583</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">namque est ille, pater quod erat meus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 6, 41</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, like nam, after an address. Aeole—namque tibi, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 65</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pleonastic, namque enim tu, credo, mi imprudenti obrepseris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 23</bibl></cit> (Ritschl, nempe enim).—Placed after a word: is namque numerus, Varr. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:3:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 3, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">virgini venienti in forum (ibi namque in tabernis litterarum ludi erant), etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 44</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:31" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">frumentum namque ex Etruriā, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 13, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:8:8" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 8, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:25:2" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 25, 2</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">22, 50, 3: frui namque pace,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 9, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:11:6" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 11, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 4, 8</bibl>; 9, 37, 1 al.; <cit><quote lang="la">omnia namque ista, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:32" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mire namque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:2:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 9, 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pinxere namque effigies herbarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 2, 4, § 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duodecim namque populos, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:5:5" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 5, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non me impia namque Tartara habent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:733" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 733</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non hoc mihi namque negares,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 614</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nana: <entryFree id="n30354" type="main" key="na_na1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. nanus, I. B.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30355" type="main" key="Nana2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nana</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n30355.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a nymph, daughter of Sangarius and mother of Atys</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 5, p. 158</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nancio: <entryFree id="n30356" type="main" key="nanci^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nancĭo</orth>, <itype>īre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">nancĭor</orth>, <itype>īri</itype>, <sense id="n30356.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. dep. a.</hi> [root nac-, v. nanciscor], <hi rend="ital">to get, gain, obtain</hi> (post-class.): si nanciam populi desiderium, Gracch. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 888</bibl> P.: in foedere Latino: PECVNIAM QVIS NANCITOR (i. e. nancitur) HABETO, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=166" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 166</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
nanciscor: <entryFree id="n30357" type="main" key="nanciscor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nanciscor</orth>, <itype>nactus and nanctus</itype> (cf. Mai. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:10:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 10, 16</bibl>; Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:30" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 30</bibl>; <sense id="n30357.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> nanciscier, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 2, 59</bibl>), 3, <hi rend="ital">v. dep. a.</hi> [Sanscr. naç, obtain; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)nek-</foreign> in <foreign lang="greek">h)/negka</foreign>, etc.; cf.: <foreign lang="greek">a)na/gkh</foreign>, necesse] (in <hi rend="ital">pass. signif</hi>, nactus, <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>), <hi rend="ital">to get, obtain, receive</hi> a thing (esp. by accident or without one's co-operation), <hi rend="ital">to meet with, stumble on, light on, find</hi> a thing (syn.: <cit><quote lang="la">offendo, reperio, deprehendo): unde anulum istum nactus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 3, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quoniam nacti te, inquit, sumus aliquando otiosum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:5:14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 5, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nactus sum etiam, qui Xenophontis similem esse se cuperet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:9:32" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 9, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum plus otii nactus ero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 7, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> N D. 3, 36, 87</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">immanes beluas nanciscimur venando,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 64, 161</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 7, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">eum Philolai commentarios esse nanctum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:10:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 10, 16</bibl></cit> Mai.: <cit><quote lang="la">Cato sic abiit a vitā, ut causam moriendi nactum se esse gauderet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:30:74" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 30, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se in silvas abdiderunt, locum nacti, egregie et naturā et opere munitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 9</bibl></cit>; hence, <hi rend="ital">to possess by birth, to have by nature</hi>: maleficam (naturam) nactus est in corpore fingendo, Nep Ages. 8; of evil as well as <pb n="1186" /> <cb n="NAR" /> good fortune: <cit><quote lang="la">quod sim nactus mali,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 6, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex nuptiis tuis si nihil nanciscor mali,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 3, 3, 10</bibl></cit>.—Esp., <hi rend="ital">to catch, contract</hi> by infection or contagion: <cit><quote lang="la">nactus est morbum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:21:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 21, 2</bibl></cit>: febrim, <hi rend="ital">to contract</hi> or <hi rend="ital">catch a fever</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tit.:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tit. 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">milvo est quoddam bellum quasi naturale cum corvo, ergo alter alterius ubicumque nactus est ova, frangit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:49:125" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 49, 125</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n30357.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to light upon, meet with, reach, find;</hi> of inanim. things or living beings: <cit><quote lang="la">meum quod rete et hami nacti sunt, meum potissimum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:3:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 3, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitis claviculis suis quicquid est nacta, complectitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:15:52" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 15, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nactus idoneam ad navigandum tempestatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nactusque silentia ruris Exululat,</quote> <trans><tr>having reached the quiet country</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:232" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 232</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nactus, as passive,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 7, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 1" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 1</bibl> and 8.</sense></entryFree>
nancitor: <entryFree id="n30358" type="main" key="nanci_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nancītor</orth>, v. nancio.</entryFree>
nanctus: <entryFree id="n30359" type="main" key="nanctus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nanctus</orth>, v. nanciscor <sense id="n30359.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">it.</hi></sense></entryFree>
nanis: <entryFree id="n30360" type="gloss" key="Nanis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nanis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>nana</etym>, <sense id="n30360.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman surname</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Fabr.</author> p. 48</bibl>, n. 269.</sense></entryFree>
nannetes: <entryFree id="n30361" type="main" key="Nanne_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nannētes</orth>, v. Namnetes.</entryFree>
nanque: <entryFree id="n30362" type="main" key="nanque"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nanque</orth>, v. namque.</entryFree>
nans: <entryFree id="n30363" type="main" key="nans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nans</orth>, <itype>nantis</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> and <pos>P. a.</pos>, v. 1. no.</entryFree>
nantuates: <entryFree id="n30364" type="main" key="Nantu^a_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nantŭātes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30364.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people in</hi> Gallia Narbonensis, <hi rend="ital">at the foot of the Alps</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 20, 24, § 137</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nanus: <entryFree id="n30365" type="greek" key="na_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">na/nnos</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">na=nos</foreign> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:13:2 sq" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 13, 2 sq.</bibl>); in vulg. lang., <sense id="n30365.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a dwarf</hi> (pure Lat. pumilio): <cit><quote lang="la">interrogatum a quodam nano,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:61" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 61</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl> (5), 8, 41; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:32" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 32</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30365.1" n="B" level="2"> In <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nāna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <hi rend="ital">a female dwarf</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nanos et nanas et moriones populo donavit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Alex. Sev. 34</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30365.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n30365.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A small horse</hi>, Helv. Cinn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:13:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 13, 5</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> § 4.—</sense><sense id="n30365.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A low, shallow water-vessel</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vas aquarium vocant futim ... quo postea accessit nanus cum Graeco nomine, et cum Latino nomine, Graecā figurā barbatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=119" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 119</bibl></cit> Müll.; cf. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=176" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 176</bibl> ib.</sense></entryFree>
napaeus: <entryFree id="n30366" type="greek" key="na^paeus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">năpaeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">napai=os</foreign>, <sense id="n30366.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a wooded vale</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dell</hi>: nymphae napaeae, <hi rend="ital">dell-nymphs</hi>, Col. poët. 10, 264. —Hence, </sense><sense id="n30366.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Năpaeae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the dell-nymphs</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">faciles venerare Napaeas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:535" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 535</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:255" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 255</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Nemes.</author> Ecl. 2, 20</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nape: <entryFree id="n30367" type="main" key="Na^pe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Năpē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n30367.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a dog</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:214" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 214</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30367.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a woman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:12:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 1, 12, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naphtha: <entryFree id="n30368" type="greek" key="naphtha"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naphtha</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">napthas</orth>, Sall. ap. Prob. Cathol. 1465 P.), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">h( na/fqa</foreign> (collat. form of <foreign lang="greek">o( na/fqas</foreign>), <sense id="n30368.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">naphtha</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">similis (maithae) est natura naphthae: ita appellatur circa Babyloniam et in Astacenis Parthiae profluens bituminis liquidi modo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:235" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 105, 109, § 235</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 17, 101, § 158</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:179" default="NO" valid="yes">35, 15, 51, § 179</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 23, 6, 38</bibl> (called oleum incendiarium, <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 4, 8</bibl> and 18; and: <cit><quote lang="la">oleum vivum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Grat.</author> Cyn. 434</bibl></cit>).</sense></entryFree>
napina: <entryFree id="n30369" type="main" key="na_pi_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāpīna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>napus</etym>, <sense id="n30369.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a turnip-field</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:71" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 2, 71</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
napurae: <entryFree id="n30370" type="gloss" key="napurae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">napurae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n30370.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">straw ropes</hi>: nectere ligare significat ... pontifex minor ex stramentis napuras nectito, id est funiculos facito, quibus sues annectantur, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. nectere, p. 165 Müll.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> p. 169.</sense></entryFree>
napus: <entryFree id="n30371" type="main" key="na_pus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāpus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30371.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of turnip, a navew</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:10:23" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 10, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:56:1" default="NO">12, 56, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 13, 35, § 131</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:75" default="NO" valid="yes">19, 5, 25, § 75</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:20" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 13, 20</bibl> <hi rend="ital">in lemm</hi>.</sense></entryFree>
napy: <entryFree id="n30372" type="greek" key="na_py"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāpy</orth>, <itype>yŏs</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">na=pu</foreign> (an old form for <foreign lang="greek">si/napi</foreign>), <sense id="n30372.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">mustard</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sinapi Athenienses napy appellaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:171" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 8, 54, § 171</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alterum thlaspi aliqui Persicum napy appellaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 13, 113, § 140</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nar: <entryFree id="n30373" type="main" key="Na_r1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nār</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Nāris</orth>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*na/r</foreign>, <sense id="n30373.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river of Italy, which rises in the Apennines, flows through a part of the Sabine territory and Umbria, and joins the Tiber</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Nera</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nar amnis exhaurit illos (Velinos lacus) sulphureis aquis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 12, 17, § 109</bibl></cit>; cf.: Solporeas posuit spiramina Naris ad undas, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 691</bibl> P. (Ann. v. 265 Vahl.); and: <cit><quote lang="la">audiit amnis Sulfureā Nar albus aquā fontesque Velini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:517" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 517</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 12</bibl> de deis; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:330" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 330</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod Lacus Velinus in Narem defluit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:15:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 15, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nare ac mox Tiberi devectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30374" type="main" key="Nar2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nar</orth>, Nartis; only <number>plur.</number>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nartes</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30374.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">dwellers on the banks of the Nar</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Interamnates, cognomine Nartes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3</bibl></cit>, <cb n="NARI" /> 14, 19, § 113; <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Interamnatium Nartium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 407, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30375" type="main" key="Nar3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nar</orth>, <itype>Nartis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30375.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river of Illyria</hi>, Mela, 2, 3, 13.</sense></entryFree>
narbo: <entryFree id="n30376" type="main" key="Narbo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Narbo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, and (late Lat.) <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nar-bōna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, also with the appellation Marcius (after the consul Q. Marcius Rex, who led a colony thither A. U. C. 636), <sense id="n30376.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Gaul, from which</hi> Gallia Narbonensis <hi rend="ital">takes its name</hi>, the mod. <hi rend="ital">Narbonne</hi>.—Form Narbo, Mela, 2, 5, 2; 6; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 4, 5, § 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Font. 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">16, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:15:5" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 15, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:8:1" default="NO">2, 8, 1</bibl>.— Form Narbona, Capitol. Max. et Balb. 5, 8; <bibl default="NO"><author>Eutr.</author> 4, 23</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 218</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n30376.1" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Narbōnensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Narbo, Narbonian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">colonia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:43:160" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 43, 160</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:51:140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 51, 140</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">coloni Narbonenses,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Font. 2, 14</bibl></cit>: Gallia, <hi rend="ital">the province of Gaul beyond the Alps</hi>, Mela, 2, 5, 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 17, 31, § 105</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30376.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Narbōnĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Narbo</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to Narbonian Gaul, Narbonian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 3, 4, § 43</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
narce: <entryFree id="n30377" type="greek" key="narce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">narcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">na/rkh</foreign>, <sense id="n30377.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a numbness, torpor</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">a narce narcissus dictus, non a fabuloso puero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 19, 75, § 128</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
narcissinus: <entryFree id="n30378" type="greek" key="narcissi^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">narcissĭnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">narki/ssinos</foreign>, <sense id="n30378.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">from the narcissus, narcissus-</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oleum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 19, 75, § 129</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unguentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 13, 1, 2, § 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
narcissitis: <entryFree id="n30379" type="greek" key="narcissi_tis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">narcissītis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">narkissi=tis</foreign>, <sense id="n30379.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a precious stone</hi>, otherwise unknown, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 11, 73, § 188</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
narcissus: <entryFree id="n30380" type="main" key="narcissus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">narcissus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">na/rkissos</foreign>, <sense id="n30380.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the narcissus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 5, 12, § 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:128" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 19, 75, § 128</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 4, 123</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">160</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30381" type="main" key="Narcissus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Narcissus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30381.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Narcissus, the son of Cephisus and the nymph Liriope. He was exceedingly beautiful, and fell so violently in love with himself on beholding his image in a fountain, that he wasted away with desire, until he was changed into the flower of the same name</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:407 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 407 sq.</bibl> —</sense><sense id="n30381.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Narcissus, a freedman of Claudius, by whose orders Messalina was put to death</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 29</bibl> sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:329" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 329</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nardifer: <entryFree id="n30382" type="main" key="nardi^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nardĭfer</orth>, <itype>ĕra, ĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nardus-fero</etym>, <sense id="n30382.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nard-bearing</hi> Ganges, <bibl default="NO"><author>Grat.</author> Cyn. 314</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nardinus: <entryFree id="n30383" type="greek" key="nardi^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nardĭnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">na/rdinos</foreign>. <sense id="n30383.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">made of nard, nard-</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">unguentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 1, 2, § 15</bibl></cit>.—As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nardĭ-num</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. vinum), <hi rend="ital">wine flavored with nard</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">deprompsit nardini amphoram cellarius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 2, 11</bibl></cit> Brix ad loc.—</sense><sense id="n30383.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Resembling nard</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pira,</quote> <trans><tr>that smell like nard</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 15, 16, § 55</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nardostachyon: <entryFree id="n30384" type="greek" key="nardosta^chy^on"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nardostăchyon</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nardo/staxus</foreign>, <sense id="n30384.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">spikenard</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2003,001:7:6:section=282" default="NO"><author>Apic.</author> 7, 6, § 282</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2003,001:8:2:section=347" default="NO">8, 2, § 347</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> de Diaet. 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nardostatius: <entryFree id="n30385" type="main" key="nardostati^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nardostatĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30385.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">spikenard</hi>, i. q. nardostachyon, <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> de Diaet. 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nardus: <entryFree id="n30386" type="greek" key="nardus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nardus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">nardum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">na/rdos</foreign>, <sense id="n30386.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nard</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 12, 26, § 42</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nardus Gallicus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 12, 12, 26, § 46</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30386.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">nard-balsam, nard-oil</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Assyriāque nardo Potamus uncti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:11:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 11, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Syrio madefactus tempora nardo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:6:63" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 3, 6, 63</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nares: <entryFree id="n30387" type="main" key="na_res"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāres</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, v. naris.</entryFree>
narinosus: <entryFree id="n30388" type="hapax" key="na_ri^no_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nārĭnōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>naris</etym>, <sense id="n30388.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">broadnosed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum diis suis narinosis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 5, 12, 13</bibl></cit> dub. (al. varicosis, cariosis, curiosis).</sense></entryFree>
nariputens: <entryFree id="n30389" type="main" key="na_ri^pu^tens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nārĭpŭtens</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-trens</orth>), <itype>entis</itype> <etym>narisputeo</etym>, <sense id="n30389.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">offensive in the nose</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Anthol. Lat.</author> 5, 205, 4</bibl> (1134, 4 Burm.).</sense></entryFree>
naris: <entryFree id="n30390" type="main" key="na_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāris</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>for nasis, from root na-; Sanscr. nārā, water; nāsā, nose; kindred to nasus; cf.: no, nāre</etym>, <sense id="n30390.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a nostril</hi>, usually in <number>plur.</number>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">nāres</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the nostrils, the nose.</hi> </sense><sense id="n30390.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n30390.2" n="(a)" level="5"> In <number>sing.</number> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in postclass. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">et lati rictūs et panda loquenti Naris erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:675" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 675</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 141</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 253</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:520" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 1, 520</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:1:33" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 1, 33</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Grat.</author> Cyn. 172</bibl>; Macer. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 82</bibl> P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 8, p. 213</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 1, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30390.3" n="(b)" level="5"> In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">nares, eo, quod omnis odor ad supera fertur, recte sursum sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:56:141" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 56, 141</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nares contractiores habent introitus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 57, 145</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fasciculum ad nares admovere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:18:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 3, 18, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mediis in naribus ingens gibbus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:108" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 108</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">patulis captavit naribus auras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:376"
